questions.text: What is the appropriate serum plasma concentration of lithium for treatment and prophylaxis of mania?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

0.6-1.5 mEq/L Mania is a period of 1 week or more in which a person experiences a change in normal behaviour that drastically affects their functioning . The defining characteristics of mania include increased talkativeness, rapid speech, a decreased need for sleep, racing thoughts, distractibility, increase in goal-directed activity, and psychomotor agitation. The therapeutic range is 1.0 to 1.5 mEq/L for acute treatment and 0.6 to 1.2 mEq/L for chronic therapy. Monitoring should be done every 1 to 2 weeks until reaching the desired therapeutic levels. Then, check lithium levels every 2 to 3 months for six months. It is also important to monitor patients for dehydration and lower the dose when there are signs of infection, excessive sweating, or diarrhea. Toxic levels are when the drug level is more than 2 mEq/L.

questions.text: Hemolysis in glucose 6 phosphate deficiency can manifest with which of the following drugs:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Primaquine G6PD deficiency is an X-linked recessive disorder that causes congenital hemolytic anaemia due to enzyme deficiency. Hemolysis occurs in conditions of high oxidative stress that are triggered by infections, fava beans, and certain drugs . G6PD is an enzyme in the hexose monophosphate pathway (HMP) that maintains the cellular levels of NADPH . NADPH then provides reducing equivalents needed for the conversion of oxidised glutathione to reduced glutathione. Reduced glutathione helps neutralise free radicals, protecting against oxidant injury. Clinically, most patients are asymptomatic. Both primaquine and chloroquine cause hemolysis in G6PD-deficient individuals, but hemolysis is rare with chloroquine and it can be used in patients with G6PD deficiency, whereas primaquine is contraindicated in these individuals.

Solution:

Highyeild:

DPP-4 is a ubiquitous enzyme that acts on incretin hormones, mainly GLP-1 (glucagon-like peptide-1) and GIP (glucose dependent insulinotroipc polypeptide), which maintain glucose homeostasis by increasing insulin secretion and decreasing glucagon secretion By inhibiting the DPP-4 enzyme, DPP-4 inhibitors increase the levels of GLP-1 and GIP, which in turn increase beta-cell insulin secretion in the pancreas, thereby reducing postprandial and fasting hyperglycemia Adverse effects : upper respiratory tract infection, nasopharyngitis, headache, urinary tract infection, arthralgia Contraindication : Type 1 diabetes - Dose adjustments are necessary for patients with renal insufficiency in all except Linagliptin as it is cleared by the hepatobiliary system

Glimepiride lowers blood sugar by causing the pancreas to produce insulin (a natural substance that is needed to break down sugar in the body) and helping the body use insulin efficiently. This medication will only help lower blood sugar in people whose bodies produce insulin naturally. Glimepiride is not used to treat type 1 diabetes (condition in which the body does not produce insulin and, therefore, cannot control the amount of sugar in the blood) or diabetic ketoacidosis (a serious condition that may occur if high blood sugar is not treated. Option B - Exenatide is in a class of medications called incretin mimetics. It works by stimulating the pancreas to secrete insulin when blood sugar levels are high. Insulin helps move sugar from the blood into other body tissues where it is used for energy. Option C - Metformin is a medicine used together with diet to lower high blood sugar levels in patients with type 2 diabetes. Metformin works by lowering the amount of glucose absorbed from intestines, decreasing how much glucose is made in the liver and improving insulin sensitivity.
